clinical_study.brief_title: The Effect of Postoperative "Peanut Ball" Rehabilitation After Total Knee Replacement.
clinical_study.official_title: The Effect of Postoperative Rehabilitation With a "Peanut Ball" After Total Knee Replacement. A Randomized Study Evaluating Postoperative Pain and Knee Function.

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this randomized controlled study is to evaluate the effect of postoperative exercise with a "peanut ball" after total knee replacement, on pain reduction, intake of pain killers, knee function, and health-related quality of life.

detailed_description.textblock: After being informed about the study and potential risks, all patients giving written informed consent will be included in the study. Each week is randomized to be either "peanut ball" och standard exercise week, with all patients during that week receiving the same treatment. Thus, depending on what week the patients are operated they will be mobilized with postoperative exercise with a "peanut ball" or to a standard exercise program (no peanut ball) 3-5 times/day for 6 weeks. The inclusion criteria will be all patients with primary osteoarthritis planed for total knee replacement at Skånes university hospital and the exclusion criteria are patients that do not understand the Swedish language, patients with dementia, revisions surgery, and unicompartmental knee replacement. Pain, intake of painkillers, range of movement, health-related quality of life, and the function will be assessed before surgery, at the ward, at 2 weeks follow-up visit, at 3-month follow-up, and at 1 year.

The rehabilitation program lasts for 15 minutes per session and is performed at least 3-5 times per day for 6 weeks. The rehabilitation program consists of standard mobility- and functional training exercises without a "peanut ball".

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patients with osteoarthritis planned for surgery with total knee replacement at Skåne University Hospital.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patients who do not understand and talk the Swedish language
- Patients with dementia
- Revision surgery of the knee
- Unicompartmentmental knee replacement
